articles.headline: You Should Freeze Your Child’s Credit. It’s Not Hard. Here’s How.
articles.snippet: A new law requiring credit bureaus to offer you free freezes applies to children, too. It’s easier than you’d expect, but you may still have questions. Here are some answers.
articles.abstract: A new law requiring credit bureaus to offer you free freezes applies to children, too. It’s easier than you’d expect, but you may still have questions. Here are some answers.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can now freeze your child’s credit files for free — and it isn’t as difficult as even the most cynical among you might expect it to be.

articles.headline: On the Front Line of the Saudi War in Yemen: Child Soldiers From Darfur
articles.snippet: Led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the Saudis have used their oil wealth to outsource the war, primarily by hiring desperate survivors of Sudan’s conflict.
articles.abstract: Led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the Saudis have used their oil wealth to outsource the war, primarily by hiring desperate survivors of Sudan’s conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — The civil war in Darfur robbed Hager Shomo Ahmed of almost any hope. Raiders had stolen his family’s cattle, and a dozen years of bloodshed had left his parents destitute.

articles.headline: A Week Into Government Shutdown, Ire Turns to Fear for Federal Workers
articles.snippet: Government workers at first thought they were looking at the kind of ho-hum political brinkmanship they’ve become used to. Things look a lot more worrisome now.
articles.abstract: Government workers at first thought they were looking at the kind of ho-hum political brinkmanship they’ve become used to. Things look a lot more worrisome now.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the government shutdown began a week ago, many federal workers were more irked than anxious.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Mitch Smith and Kate Taylor

articles.headline: Carlos Ghosn’s Daughters See a Nissan Revolt Behind His Arrest
articles.snippet: Breaking a silence, Caroline and Maya Ghosn said they suspected that talk of “reimagining the alliance” with Renault had played a role in their father’s ouster on allegations of financial misconduct.
articles.abstract: Breaking a silence, Caroline and Maya Ghosn said they suspected that talk of “reimagining the alliance” with Renault had played a role in their father’s ouster on allegations of financial misconduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: The children of Carlos Ghosn, the jailed auto executive who oversaw an alliance that sold more than 10 million cars a year, believe accusations of financial misconduct against him are part of a revolt within Nissan against exploring a possible merger with Renault.

articles.headline: Kamala Harris, Elizabeth Warren and Other Democrats Shift Into High Gear for 2020
articles.snippet: Cory Booker and Kirsten Gillibrand are two other Democratic senators who are also finalizing the outlines of presidential bids that may start within weeks.
articles.abstract: Cory Booker and Kirsten Gillibrand are two other Democratic senators who are also finalizing the outlines of presidential bids that may start within weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Kamala Harris of California is eyeing Baltimore or Atlanta as a possible base of operations for her likely 2020 presidential bid and is close to bringing on a top aide to run her campaign.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: He Was a Gay Man on Staff at a Catholic Parish. Then the Threats Began Coming In.
articles.snippet: Some Catholic parishes have quietly welcomed gay parishioners and staff. But in the aftermath of the sex abuse crisis, there is a campaign to push them out.
articles.abstract: Some Catholic parishes have quietly welcomed gay parishioners and staff. But in the aftermath of the sex abuse crisis, there is a campaign to push them out.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — When Antonio Aaron Bianco arrived for work at his Roman Catholic church office on a recent Monday morning, he was rattled to discover that someone had broken into the conference room and spray-painted a message in large yellow letters on the wall. It said “No Fags.”

articles.headline: A Day, a Life: When a Medic Was Killed in Gaza, Was It an Accident?
articles.snippet: When an Israeli soldier killed Rouzan al-Najjar, Palestinians called her an innocent martyr. Israel portrayed her as a threat. The truth is more complicated.
articles.abstract: When an Israeli soldier killed Rouzan al-Najjar, Palestinians called her an innocent martyr. Israel portrayed her as a threat. The truth is more complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHUZAA, Gaza Strip — A young medic in a head scarf runs into danger, her only protection a white lab coat. Through a haze of tear gas and black smoke, she tries to reach a man sprawled on the ground along the Gaza border. Israeli soldiers, their weapons leveled, watch warily from the other side.

articles.headline: The Rise and Fall of Carlos Ghosn
articles.snippet: Mr. Ghosn, the ousted Nissan executive, wasn’t supposed to succeed in Japan, but he never expected to fail like this. He faces charges of financial wrongdoing at the company he helped save.
articles.abstract: Mr. Ghosn, the ousted Nissan executive, wasn’t supposed to succeed in Japan, but he never expected to fail like this. He faces charges of financial wrongdoing at the company he helped save.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carlos Ghosn was tired. At 64 years old, the chairman of an auto empire that spanned several continents and included Nissan, Renault and Mitsubishi wasn’t bouncing back from jet lag the way he used to. Melatonin wasn’t working anymore, and he had bouts of insomnia, phoning his children in the middle of the night or going on long walks around his Tokyo or Paris neighborhood. He planned to retire soon, stepping back from spending his life on an airplane, albeit a luxurious one paid for by Nissan.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Motoko Rich

articles.headline: Cyberattack Disrupts Printing of Major Newspapers
articles.snippet: Malware was focused on networks used by Tribune Publishing, former owner of The Los Angeles Times. It was the first known attack on newspaper printing operations.
articles.abstract: Malware was focused on networks used by Tribune Publishing, former owner of The Los Angeles Times. It was the first known attack on newspaper printing operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Times says an unusual cyberattack that disrupted its printing operations and those at newspapers in San Diego and Florida over the weekend came from outside the United States, but it stopped short of accusing a specific foreign government.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Facebook Data Scandals Stoke Criticism That a Privacy Watchdog Too Rarely Bites
articles.snippet: A federal regulator is under attack for what critics say is a systemic failure to police tech giants and their vast appetite for personal data.
articles.abstract: A federal regulator is under attack for what critics say is a systemic failure to police tech giants and their vast appetite for personal data.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last spring, soon after Facebook acknowledged that the data of tens of millions of its users had improperly been obtained by the political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica, a top enforcement official at the Federal Trade Commission drafted a memo about the prospect of disciplining the social network.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Empty Homes and Protests: China’s Property Market Strains the World
articles.snippet: A glut of unwanted apartments gets part of the blame for a slowdown in the world’s second-largest economy. In some places, homeowners are taking to the streets.
articles.abstract: A glut of unwanted apartments gets part of the blame for a slowdown in the world’s second-largest economy. In some places, homeowners are taking to the streets.
articles.lead_paragraph: JURONG, China — For Hu Peiliang, Jurong was a city of cranes, concrete and opportunity. He was so sure it was on the cusp of a boom that last year he moved his family there.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: ‘Exhibit A’: How McKinsey Got Entangled in a Bribery Case
articles.snippet: The consultancy’s report became key evidence in a battle over the extradition of a powerful Ukrainian oligarch charged in a scheme to help Boeing.
articles.abstract: The consultancy’s report became key evidence in a battle over the extradition of a powerful Ukrainian oligarch charged in a scheme to help Boeing.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Boeing was in a tight spot. Just as it was preparing to roll out its innovative 787 Dreamliner — the plane that was supposed to lead the aircraft manufacturer into the future — a shortage of strong but lightweight titanium parts threatened production.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: Trump Digs In, Darkening Hopes for a Deal to End the Shutdown
articles.snippet: The president has repeatedly called allies, reassuring them that he will not yield on his wall demands. But he has not reached out to Democrats, whose votes he needs for a deal.
articles.abstract: The president has repeatedly called allies, reassuring them that he will not yield on his wall demands. But he has not reached out to Democrats, whose votes he needs for a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The television is on. The phone is never far away. And President Trump is repeatedly calling allies such as members of Congress and conservative radio hosts, telling them privately that he will not give in on his demand for funding for a border wall.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: In Orange County, a Republican Fortress Turns Democratic
articles.snippet: The Democratic sweep in Orange County is the latest sign of a huge political and cultural shift in a former Republican stronghold.
articles.abstract: The Democratic sweep in Orange County is the latest sign of a huge political and cultural shift in a former Republican stronghold.
articles.lead_paragraph: WESTMINSTER, Calif. — To appreciate the vast cultural and political upheaval across Orange County over the last 40 years, look no further than Bolsa Avenue. The auto body shop, the tax preparer, a church, a food market, countless restaurants — all are marked by signs written in Vietnamese.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: C.I.A.’s Afghan Forces Leave a Trail of Abuse and Anger
articles.snippet: The fighters hold the line in the war’s toughest spots, but officials say their brutal tactics are terrorizing the public and undermining the U.S. mission.
articles.abstract: The fighters hold the line in the war’s toughest spots, but officials say their brutal tactics are terrorizing the public and undermining the U.S. mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: NADER SHAH KOT, Afghanistan — Razo Khan woke up suddenly to the sight of assault rifles pointed at his face, and demands that he get out of bed and onto the floor.

articles.headline: Elizabeth Warren Announces Iowa Trip as She Starts Running for President in 2020
articles.snippet: Senator Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat, said she was forming a presidential exploratory committee, which allows her to raise money and hire staff before a formal kickoff.
articles.abstract: Senator Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat, said she was forming a presidential exploratory committee, which allows her to raise money and hire staff before a formal kickoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat and a sharp critic of big banks and unregulated capitalism, entered the 2020 race for president on Monday, becoming the first major candidate in what is likely to be a long and crowded primary marked by ideological and generational divisions in a Democratic Party determined to beat President Trump.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon and Alexander Burns
